likely_uncovered_areas_or_ambiguities: Detailed behavior, edge cases, and UI flows for each specific board tool (e.g., individual chart types, code blocks, clustering options) beyond the high-level Help Center category listing.
Exact field-level data models, constraints, and error semantics for all REST, Web SDK, SCIM, and Live Embed APIs, as only their category-level documentation and reference indexes were reviewed.
Full configuration surface of Enterprise Guard (all rule options, detection patterns, retention exceptions) and how it interacts with different regional data residency setups.
Precise mapping of each enterprise security/compliance control to specific certifications and regulatory obligations (e.g., which features are required for HIPAA vs. SOC 2 vs. ISO 27001 scenarios).
Mobile, desktop, and interactive display client behavior in offline or low-connectivity scenarios (local caching, encryption at rest on clients, and sync conflict handling).
Fine-grained AI governance options (per‑team or per‑format AI restrictions, LLM provider choices, log retention of prompts/responses) beyond what is stated in public AI and Enterprise Guard docs.
assumptions_made: Help Center category indexes provide a reasonably complete list of major user-facing capabilities, even though individual article content was not exhaustively crawled.
The Developer Platform introduction accurately reflects the primary API surfaces (Web SDK, REST API, Marketplace, SCIM API, Live Embed) used by third parties and internal integrations.

Security and Enterprise Guard marketing/overview pages faithfully describe the high-level behavior of automated discovery, classification, guardrails, retention, and encryption key management, even if implementation details are abstracted.
The current public documentation is up-to-date as of late 2025, and older references (e.g., to "Beta" features) still roughly describe behavior where no newer contradictory documentation is visible.
Common SaaS patterns (e.g., autosave, multi-tenant isolation, eventual consistency) apply unless documentation explicitly suggests otherwise.

Frames, shapes, cards, charts, text boxes, code blocks, connectors
Comments and annotations
Embedded media (images, documents, external embeds)

Canvas content frequently contains intellectual property and sensitive business information (e.g., roadmaps, architecture diagrams).

privileged_operations: Configuring SAML SSO, domain control, SCIM, JIT, and 2FA settings for an organization via the Admin Console and Enterprise Integrations.
Enabling and managing Enterprise Guard, including classification policies, Intelligent Guardrails, retention rules, and encryption key management with AWS KMS.
Creating, merging, or deleting Enterprise teams; consolidating self‑serve teams into the Enterprise subscription; and granting admin roles or custom admin privileges.
Managing app allowlists/blocklists, app requests, Enterprise Developer Teams, and controlling whether Miro boards can be embedded in external apps.
Configuring Enterprise Integrations (SCIM, SIEM, SAM, Bring your own AI), which can alter identity, monitoring, and AI data flows at scale.
Exporting large volumes of content or legal-discovery datasets via eDiscovery and export tools.
user_configurable_logic: Board- and space-level sharing defaults (who can view/edit/comment, link visibility, copy/export restrictions) controlled by board owners and admins.
Enterprise Guard policies for discovery, classification, retention, and guardrails configured by security/compliance teams, effectively encoding DLP logic inside Miro.
AI governance settings (e.g., who can use Miro AI, credit allocation, bring-your-own AI configurations) adjustable per organization or team.
Admin Analytics and Miro Insights dashboards, where filters and views can be configured to focus on particular teams, users, or boards.
Admin Announcements and Product Announcements portal, which allow admins to craft and target in‑product messages to segments of users.
auth_and_identity_behaviours: Supports SAML-based SSO with IdP-driven attributes, disabling password/Google/Slack logins once enabled, and relies on domain verification to define managed users.
Offers Just-in-Time provisioning (JIT) tied to SSO so new corporate-domain users are auto‑added to specified teams; supports SCIM for more granular lifecycle control.
Allows multi-factor authentication (2FA) for users outside SSO; 2FA is recommended especially when SSO is not used or for non-managed domains.
Uses domain control to ensure only verified corporate domains produce managed users forced through SSO, while unverified domains rely on email/password.
Encourages creation of a 'break glass' account outside managed domains to avoid full admin lockout in case of SSO issues.
SCIM API includes safeguards like blocking email changes that would move users outside managed domains, returning validation errors instead.
logging_and_audit_behaviours: Board history, activity lists, and Catch Up features provide per‑board logs of changes, including who performed them and when.
Enterprise Guard event logging tracks classification, guardrail enforcement, retention, and key events, with options to expose them via Discovery or logging APIs.
Enterprise Integrations enable exporting audit logs to SIEM solutions for centralized monitoring and correlation with other systems.
Admin Analytics and Miro Insights aggregate activity data into dashboards rather than raw event views, suitable for operational oversight rather than forensic deep dives.
Security documentation emphasizes regular vulnerability management and penetration testing, suggesting internal logging for security operations.
failure_modes: Incorrect SSO configuration or domain control can prevent users or admins from logging in; docs recommend break‑glass accounts and support involvement to disable SSO if necessary.
SCIM misconfiguration or IdP issues may result in users not being provisioned or unexpectedly deactivated; docs note allowlist and multi‑IdP edge cases.
Enterprise Guard classification or retention misconfiguration can either over-block collaboration (too restrictive) or under-protect sensitive data (too permissive).
App or integration misconfigurations (e.g., mis-scoped OAuth tokens, embed permissions) can inadvertently expose content within third‑party tools or to external users.
Service outages or degraded performance are surfaced through the Miro Status page and may affect collaboration, AI features, or admin operations.

Login issues (including SSO and email/password problems) and board access or performance issues have dedicated troubleshooting guides in the Help Center, indicating known classes of operational failures.
